member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenArbitrarySequence
member.summary: Provides functionality for configuring, defining, and clearing an arbitrary sequence.
member.remarks:
Use this class to create and configure arbitrary sequences. An arbitrary sequence is a sequence of waveforms you would like the signal generator to generate. You can use this class to define what waveforms you would like to be generated in the sequence, as well as how many times you would like each waveform to generate.
This class cannot be instantiated directly. It is instantiated when the
session object is created. Access this class using .

member.summary: Gets the maximum sequence depth - that is, the number of times a sequence can include other sequences recursively. A depth of zero indicates the generator supports waveforms only. member.param: The array of waveform handles from which you want to create a new arbitrary sequence.
The array of loop counts that you want to use to create a new arbitrary sequence.

The array of sample counts that you want to use to create a new arbitrary waveform. These values indicate the subset, in samples, of the given waveform to generate. Each element must be larger than the minimum waveform size, a multiple of the waveform quantum, and no larger than the number of samples in the corresponding waveform.
The array of marker locations where you want a marker to be generated in the sequence. The marker location must be less than the size of the waveform the marker is in. Use -1 to specify no marker.

Upon return, contains the values of all given markers that are coerced (rounded) to the nearest marker quantum.
Not all devices coerce markers.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenDataMarkerEvent
member.summary: Provides functionality for configuring data marker events.
member.remarks:
A data marker is an event that the signal generator generates in relation to the data bits of a waveform that is generated. Up to four bits can be configured to export any valid destination on the signal generator. Refer to Data Marker Events in the NI Signal Generators Help for more information.
This class cannot be instantiated directly. It is instantiated when the
session object is created. Access this class using .

member.summary: Gets or sets the source terminal for the digital edge start trigger.
member.value: The source terminal for the digital edge start trigger.

remarks.para:
This property is used only when is set to .
You can specify any valid source terminal for this property. Source terminals can be specified in two ways. If your device is named Dev1 and your terminal is PFI0, then the terminal can be specified as a fully qualified terminal name, "/Dev1/PFI0". You can also specify the terminal using PFI 0. For a list of the terminals available on your device, refer to the Routes topic for your device or to the Device Routes tab in MAX.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenDoneEvent
member.summary: Provides properties used to configure and monitor Done events.
member.remarks:
Use this class to configure and monitor Done events. A "Done" event is a signal sent by the signal generator indicating that waveform generation is complete. A Done event can be a level or pulse signal. Use this class to configure the signal and determine its destination terminal.
This class cannot be instantiated directly. It is instantiated when the
session object is created. Access this class using .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenDoneEvent.Delay
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount by which to delay a done event with respect to the end of the analog output of the signal generator.
member.value: The amount to delay a done event with respect to the end of the analog output of the signal generator. The default value is 0.
member.remarks: A "Done" event is a signal sent by the signal generator indicating that waveform generation is complete. A positive delay value indicates that the done event occurs after the analog data output, while a negative delay value indicates that the done event occurs before the analog data output. Using the default value (0) aligns the done event with the analog output. You can specify the units of the delay value by setting the property.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenDataTransfer.MaximumInFlightReads
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of concurrent PCI Express read requests the signal generator can issue.
member.value: The maximum number of concurrent PCI Express read requests the signal generator can issue. The default value is the highest value the signal generator supports.

remarks.para: When transferring data from computer memory to device onboard memory across the PCI Express bus, the signal generator can issue multiple memory reads at the same time. In general, the larger the number of read requests, the more efficiently the device uses the bus. This efficiency is caused by the multiple read requests that keep data flowing, even in a PCI Express topology that has high latency due to PCI Express switches in the data path. Most NI devices can issue a large number of read requests, typically 8 or 16. By default, this property is set to the highest value the signal generator supports.

If other devices in your system cannot tolerate long data latencies, it may be helpful to decrease the number of in-flight read requests the signal generator issues. This change helps to reduce the amount of data the signal generator reads at one time.
You cannot change this property while the device is generating a waveform. If you want to change the device configuration, call
or wait for the generation to complete.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenDataTransfer.PreferredPacketSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the preferred size of the data field in a PCI Express read request packet.
member.value: The preferred size of the data field in a PCI Express read request packet. The default value is the largest packet size allowed by the system.
member.remarks:
In general, the larger the packet size, the more efficiently the device uses the bus. By default, NI signal generators use the largest packet size allowed by the system. However, because of different system implementations, some systems may perform better with smaller packet sizes.
Recommended values for this property are powers of two between 64 and 512.
In some cases, the signal generator generates packets smaller than the preferred size you set with this property.
You cannot change this property while the device is generating a waveform. If you want to change the device configuration, call
or wait for the generation to complete.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenDriverUtility.ImportAttributeConfigurationFile(System.String)
member.summary: Imports a configuration to the session from the specified file.
member.remarks:
You can export and import supported configurations only between NI-FGEN devices with identical bus types, model numbers, and channel counts, as well as the same number of initialized channels. You cannot call this method while the session is in the Running/Generating state.
Supported Configurations You can export and import the following between NI-FGEN sessions:
Attribute configurations
Arbitrary waveforms
Requirements for Exporting and Importing Arbitrary Waveforms Arbitrary waveforms you export and import between sessions using this method must meet the following criteria:
All waveforms in the exporting session are created from files, other than HWS files, using the or methods
The full file path of the file containing the arbitrary waveform still exists upon import
All waveforms are defined using handles rather than names
All waveforms are complete; none are streamed or incrementally written
You can set the device mode with the FgenOutput.OutputMode property. For more information on arbitrary waveform mode, refer to Arbitrary Waveform Output Mode and Configure Arbitrary Waveform Mode.
Channel Mapping Behavior When exporting and importing configurations between NI-FGEN sessions that were initialized with different channels, the configuration of the exporting channel is mapped to the importing channel. For example, if channel 0 is initialized for the exporting session and channel 1 is initialized for the importing session, the configuration exported from channel 0 is imported into channel 1. NI-FGEN will return an if the total number of channels initialized for the exporting session is not equal to the total number of channels initialized for the importing session.
member.param: The absolute path to the file that contains the configuration to import. If you specify an empty or relative path, this method returns an . The default file extension is .nifgenconfig.
member.exception:
The method was called after the associated
object was disposed.

Supported Configurations You can export and import the following between NI-FGEN sessions:
Attribute configurations
Arbitrary waveforms
Requirements for Exporting and Importing Arbitrary Waveforms Arbitrary waveforms you export and import between sessions using this method must meet the following criteria:
All waveforms in the exporting session are created from files, other than HWS files, using the or methods
The full file path of the file containing the arbitrary waveform still exists upon import
All waveforms are defined using handles rather than names
All waveforms are complete; none are streamed or incrementally written
You can set the device mode with the FgenOutput.OutputMode property. For more information on arbitrary waveform mode, refer to Arbitrary Waveform Output Mode and Configure Arbitrary Waveform Mode.
Channel Mapping Behavior When exporting and importing configurations between NI-FGEN sessions that were initialized with different channels, the configuration of the exporting channel is mapped to the importing channel. For example, if channel 0 is initialized for the exporting session and channel 1 is initialized for the importing session, the configuration exported from channel 0 is imported into channel 1. NI-FGEN will return an if the total number of channels initialized for the exporting session is not equal to the total number of channels initialized for the importing session.
member.returns: Returns a array that contains the exported configuration.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenMarkerEvent
member.summary: Provides properties and methods to configure marker events.
member.remarks:
A marker is an event that the device generates in relation to a waveform that is generated. The event is configured to occur at the time of a specific location or sample n if the waveform generates on the CH 0 connector. If the waveform loops multiple times in a segment, the marker generates each time the waveform loops. Refer to Data Marker Events in the NI Signal Generators Help for more information.
This class cannot be instantiated directly. It is instantiated when the
session object is created. Access this class using .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenFrequencyList
member.summary: Provides properties and methods used for configuring frequencies and durations.
member.remarks:
Use this class to create and configure frequency lists. A frequency list is a list of frequencies and durations for which to generate a standard waveform. You can use this class to create multiple frequency lists, and then use to configure which frequency list to generate.
This class cannot be instantiated directly. It is instantiated when the
session object is created. Access this class using .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenFrequencyList.Configure(System.String,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Configures the amplitude, DC offset, and start phase for the specified frequency list.
member.param: The channel name for which you want to configure the frequency list.

The handle of the frequency list that you want the signal generator to produce. You can create a frequency list using the
method, which returns a handle that you use to identify the list.

The amplitude of the standard waveform that you want the signal generator to produce. This value is the amplitude at the output terminal. The amplitude can also be set by calling .
is in peak-to-peak voltage.

The DC offset of the standard waveform that you want the signal generator to produce. The value is the offset from ground to the center of the waveform you specify with the waveform parameter, observed at the output terminal. For example, to configure a waveform with an amplitude of 10.00 V to range from 0.00 V to +10.00 V, set to 5.00 V. The amplitude can also be set by calling .
is in volts.

The horizontal offset of the standard waveform you want the signal generator to produce. The start phase can also be set by calling . A start phase of 180 degrees means output generation begins halfway through the waveform. A start phase of 360 degrees offsets the output by an entire waveform cycle, which is identical to a start phase of 0 degrees.
Specify this parameter in degrees of one waveform cycle.
This parameter does not affect signal generator behavior when you set the waveform parameter to .
member.remarks:
The amplitude, DC offset, and start phase are specified by . These values can also be set by calling , , , and .
The signal generator must not be in the Generating state when you call this method.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenOnboardSignalProcessing.CompensateForFilterDelay
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether OSP filter group delay will be adjusted when aligning analog outputs and events in OSP mode.
member.value: A value indicating whether OSP filter group delay will be adjusted when aligning analog outputs and events in OSP mode.
member.remarks:
If you set this property to , event outputs align more closely with the analog output. The analog output also aligns more closely between two devices synchronized using NI-TClk.
Group delay is the delay that occurs as a result of passing through an FIR filter. At a low I/Q rate, the group delay can become so large that some devices may not be able to align the events with the output. In this case, you must increase the I/Q rate or disable this property.

remarks.para:
This setting can be applied in , , and . You also can use this setting in

On the NI 5411 and NI 5431, NI-FGEN adjusts signal amplitude to compensate for the filter attenuation at that frequency. To disable amplitude correction, set to 0. If the is set to , filter correction frequency typically should be set to the same value as the frequency of the standard waveform.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenReferenceClock
member.summary: Provides properties and methods to configure the signal generator reference clock source and frequency.
member.remarks:
Use this class to configure the source and frequency of the reference clock the signal generator will use.
This class cannot be instantiated directly. It is instantiated when the
session object is created. Access this class using .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenReferenceClock.Source
member.summary: Gets or sets the reference clock source used by the signal generator.
member.value: The reference clock source used by the signal generator.
member.remarks:
The signal generator derives the frequencies and sample rates that it uses to generate waveforms from the source you specify. For example, when you set this property to ClkIn, the signal generator uses the signal it receives at its CLK IN front panel connector as its reference clock. You cannot change the reference clock source while the device is generating a waveform. If you want to change the device configuration, call
or wait for the generation to complete.
The following are some values that you can use as the reference clock source:
None (None)
Specifies that reference clock is not used.
PXI Clock (PXI_Clk)
Specifies that the PXI Clock is used as the reference clock source.
Clock In (ClkIn)
Specifies that the CLK IN input signal from the front panel connector is used as the reference clock source.
Onboard reference clock (OnboardRefClk)
Specifies that the onboard reference clock is used as the reference clock source.
RTSI 7 (RTSI7)
Specifies that RTSI line 7 is used as the reference clock source.
member.exception:
was accessed after the associated
or

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenSampleClock.ClockMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the sample clock mode for the signal generator.
member.value: The sample clock mode for the signal generator.
member.remarks:
For signal generators that support it, this property allows switching the sample clock to a clocking mode.
When in sampling mode, the sample rate can only be set to certain frequencies, based on dividing down the sample clock. However, in mode, the sample rate may be set to any value.
You cannot change this property while the device is generating a waveform. If you want to change the device configuration, call method or wait for the generation to complete.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenSampleClock.Source
member.summary: Gets or sets the sample clock source.
member.value: The sample clock source. The default value is "OnboardClock".

remarks.para:
The following defined values are examples of possible sample clock sources. For a complete list of the sample clock sources available on your device, refer to the Routes topic for your device or to the Device Routes tab in MAX.
OnboardClock Specifies that the onboard clock is used as the sample clock source.
ClkIn Specifies that the signal at the CLK IN front panel connector is used as the sample clock source.
PXI_Star Specifies that the PXI star trigger line is used as the sample clock source.
PXI_Trig0 Specifies that the PXI or RTSI line 0 is used as the sample clock source.
PXI_Trig1 Specifies that the PXI or RTSI line 1 is used as the sample clock source.
PXI_Trig2 Specifies that the PXI or RTSI line 2 is used as the sample clock source.
PXI_Trig3 Specifies that the PXI or RTSI line 3 is used as the sample clock source.
PXI_Trig4 Specifies that the PXI or RTSI line 4 is used as the Sample clock source.
PXI_Trig5 Specifies that the PXI or RTSI line 5 is used as the sample clock source.
PXI_Trig6 Specifies that the PXI or RTSI line 6 is used as the sample clock source.
PXI_Trig7 Specifies that the PXI or RTSI line 7 is used as the sample clock source.
DDC_ClkIn Specifies that the sample clock from the digital data connector is used as the sample clock source.
remarks.note: You cannot change this property while the device is generating a waveform. If you want to change the device configuration, call the method or wait for the generation to complete.

member.summary: Configures the properties of the signal generator that affect standard waveform generation.
member.param: The channel to be used.
The standard waveform that you want the signal generator to produce.
The peak-to-peak amplitude of the standard waveform that you want the signal generator to produce.
The DC offset of the standard waveform that you want the signal generator to produce.
The frequency of the standard waveform that you want the signal generator to produce.
The horizontal offset, in degrees of one waveform cycle, of the standard waveform that you want the signal generator to produce.

remarks.para: When specifying the , a start phase of 180 degrees means output generation begins halfway through the waveform cycle. A start phase of 360 degrees offsets the output by an entire waveform cycle and is therefore identical to a start phase of 0 degrees.

The value of is the offset at the output terminal. The value is the offset from ground to the center of the waveform that you specify with . For example, to configure a waveform with a peak-to-peak amplitude of 10.00 V to range from 0.00 V to +10.00 V, set to 5.00 V.

or .
member.param: The channel to use.
The full path and name of the file where the waveform data resides.

The byte order of the data in the file.
Data written by most applications in Windows (including LabWindows/CVI) is in Little Endian format. Data written to a file from LabVIEW is in Big Endian format by default on all platforms. (Big Endian and Little Endian refer to the way data is stored in memory, which can differ on different processors.)
member.returns: A handle that identifies the waveform.
member.remarks: The floating-point data must be between -1.0 and +1.0.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.NIFgen.Commit
member.summary: Causes a transition to the committed state.
member.remarks:
This method verifies driver attribute values, reserves the device, and commits the attribute values to the device. If the attribute values are all valid, NI-FGEN sets the device hardware configuration to match the session configuration.
This method does not support the NI 5401/5404/5411/5431 signal generators.
In the committed state, you can load waveforms, scripts, and sequences into memory. If any driver attributes are changed, NI-FGEN implicitly transitions back to the idle state, where you can program all session properties before applying them to the device. This method has no effect if the device is already in the committed or generating state.
Calling this method before the method is optional but has the following benefits:
Routes are committed, so signals are exported or imported.
Any reference clock and external clock circuits are phase-locked.
A subsequent call to can run faster because the device is already configured.
member.exception:
was called after the associated
or
object was disposed.

The underlying NI-FGEN driver returned an error.
- or - An underlying driver attribute value was invalid.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.NIFgen.ConfigureChannels(System.String)
member.summary: Configures the channels used with the session.
member.param: The channel(s) that all subsequent channel-based properties in the session configure.
member.remarks:
If you call this method, you must immediately call it after opening the session, and before configuring any properties or writing data.
Valid values for are non-negative integers. For example, 0 is the only valid value on devices with one channel, while devices with two channels support values of 0 and 1. You can specify more than one channel by inserting commas between values (for example, "0,1").

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenOutput.GetDigitalGain(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a factor by which the signal generator digitally multiplies generated data before converting it to an analog signal in the digital-to-analog converter.
member.param: The name of the output channel.
member.returns: A factor by which the signal generator digitally multiplies generated data before converting it to an analog signal in the digital-to-analog converter. The default value is 1.0.
member.remarks:
For a digital gain greater than 1.0, the product of the digital gain times the generated data must be inside the range 1.0, assuming floating point data. If the product exceeds these limits, the signal generator clips the output signal, and an error results. Some signal generators support both digital gain and analog gain, specified with the standard waveform amplitude or arbitrary gain using
and
respectively. Digital gain can be changed during generation without the glitches that may occur when changing analog gains, due to relay switching. However, the digital-to-analog converter output resolution is a function of analog gain, so only analog gain makes full use of the resolution of the digital-to-analog converter.
member.exception:
was called after the associated
or
object was disposed.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenOutput.GetAnalogPath(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the analog signal path.
member.param: The name of the output channel.
member.returns: The analog signal path. The default value is .
member.remarks:
The path allows the user to configure gain, offset, analog filter status, output impedance, and output enable. The path presents a much smaller gain range, and you cannot adjust offset or the filter status. The path provides a smaller output range but lower distortion. The path has two amplifier options, high and low gain. Setting this value to
allows NI-FGEN to choose the amplifier based on the user-specified gain.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.FgenOutput.SetAnalogPath(System.String,NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIFgen.AnalogPath)
member.summary: Sets the analog signal path.
member.param: The name of the output channel.
The analog signal path.
member.remarks:
The main analog path allows the user to configure gain, offset, analog filter status, output impedance, and output enable. However, the direct analog path presents a much smaller gain range, and you cannot adjust offset or the filter status.
The direct analog path provides a smaller output range but lower distortion. The main path has two amplifier options: high gain and low gain. Setting this value to
allows NI-FGEN to choose the amplifier based on the user-specified gain.
